items.content_html:
Pigeons are still faster than the internet.

The idea is simple: strap as much physical storage media [3TB] on a bird as you possibly canâ€¦ Using my new Pigeon Data Transfer Equation, I can estimate a pigeon would win under its own power out to about 500 miles (800 km).

However,

The next logical step is IPoAC (IP over Avian Carriers). This communication protocol would provide more robust data transfer guarantees, though there are some potential issues. Only one serious implementation has taken flight, and that was back in 2001, in Norway: â€˜â€¦it turned out that things had been so busy at the other end that they forgot to shut the pigeon cage, and the remaining two pigeons escaped without an IP packet. There was only six return pigeons, thus we got four ping replys, with ping times varying from 3211 to 6389 seconds.â€™

55% packet loss isn’t all that great.

items.title: Alienâ€™s most harrowing [cut] scene
items.content_html:
The cocooning scene from Alien, cut from the original release, is possibly the most harrowing scene [not] in the film. It was supposed to feature towards the end of the movie, when Ripley is already the last remaining crew member alive, or at least weâ€™re led to assume. This cut scene follows a flame-thrower toting Ripley into the Alienâ€™s hive. Here, she finds crew members Dallas and Brett either metamorphosing into or being consumed by an enclosing egg. Dallas is barely alive enough to plead to Ripley to kill him, which she is reluctant to do but ultimately obliges.

The Youtube channel Alien Theory has published a deep dive into the scene including the various explanations for why the scene was cut, not least pacing. But had it remained, would it have swayed James Cameron away from introducing a queen and drones concept in the sequel Aliens?

items.title: Golden point goonage
items.content_html:
I wouldnâ€™t say Iâ€™m particularly for overtime or golden point decidersâ€”a draw is okay, right? But if only you could bottle the feeling when your teams win by one. Salford needed to defeat Warrington today to keep their hopes of reaching the play-offs alive, and both sides were clearly nervy.

Mark Sneyd scored his 2000th Super League point by kicking a penalty to make it 20â€“20 at full-time. He also had the chance to win the match in golden point extra time with his 2001st but struck the left upright with a drop goal attempt. Instead, Salford opted to go for a try down the left-hand side, which worked a treat. Cue flailing limbs and a half-hearted attempt at a pitch invasion.

Salford are at Hull KR next Saturday for another do or die showdown.

items.title: Greg Louganisâ€™s medals up for sale
items.content_html:
I donâ€™t know much about competitive diving, but I do know of Tom Daley and that Jason Statham competed for England in the Commonwealth Games before he became famous for acting. Oh and there is Greg Louganis, who I assume is one of the all-time greats but also memorable for the time he hit his head on the springboard during a dive from the 10-metre platform.

Greg is auctioning loads of memorabila inlcuding his Olympic medals for charity. The gold medal from Seoul â€™88 was for the 10-metre platform competition, during which he hit his head as mentioned earlier. He smacked his head on the way down from a dive, came back half an hour later to complete his compliment of dives, and won the comp.

items.title: Hatch, Manchester
items.content_html:
Earlier this week I came across a modernist illustration by Bo Lundberg of Hatch with the Mancunian Way in the background. A shipping container-style market of independent eateries, coffee shops, bars, breweries, clothes shops, florists etc, Iâ€™ve spent a few days and nights out there through work lunches and after work socials.

Itâ€™s a shame then that Hatch is closing soon after 6 years at short notice (September 30th), the land sold/leased to a company (Stack) who plans a similar operation but without any guarantees to the current tenants or permanent staff of continuation or redeployment. The *MENÂ *reports that these people have only a monthâ€™s notice find new premises or new jobs, though they will receive priority during recruitment, there are no certainties. Sacha Lord has offered all those affected at Hatch a job at the Warehouse Project when it returns for its new season.

items.title: We (possibly) donâ€™t need another Twitter
items.content_html:
Cal Newport blogs that we donâ€™t need another Twitter. I suppose he would say that not being a fan of attention-sapping devices. While Twitter became too big to be a nice, sane, twee, â€˜global conversation platformâ€™â€”and I generally agree that in the broadest sense Twitter had long been a home for toxic babbleâ€”there are use cases for good that may be left unfulfilled if the Twitter we knew ceases to be. For example, academic Twitter.

Mark Carrigan asks where academics will turn:

My broader concern is that universities are still pushingâ€¦ that every upwardly mobile ambitious academic needs to be highly visible on the dominant platform and be seen engaging on a regular basis. That was always bad advice, and, now, it is becoming counterproductive and, in some cases, dangerous, adviceâ€¦

Twitter facilitated a social infrastructure for academic life in which a limited few with a big social media footprint were able to leverage it to advantage in their academic career, with greater visibility for their publications, a wide network and lots of opportunities. As that breaks down, our academic communities need to get much better at facilitating other modes of engagement so that we are never again so reliant on a big corporate platformâ€¦

Iâ€™m increasingly convinced there isnâ€™t going to be one single Twitter alternative because the marketplace of Twitter alternatives is so crowded. For an individual academic, the key is to experiment with a platform to get a sense of whether it worksâ€¦

Gina Sipley argues that even if Twitter manages to stabilise and maintain the trust of academics it will still block one the main benefitsâ€”leveraging their biggest audience, lurkers:

Lurking is a lucrative form of social media participation for platforms, if the lurker is logged in and the micrometrics of their reading history can be tracked. Content creators and influencers want their tweets to be seen by the largest possible audience; putting restrictions on lurking benefits the platform, not the creatorâ€¦

Twitter Blue subscribers have access to a reader mode, which declutters the reading experience by displaying fewer ads. By enhancing the reading experience one can more leisurely lurk. However, the cost of subscribing to Twitter Blue reinforces the privileged position of the lurker. Without a subscription to Twitter Blue, lurking is a less enjoyable experienceâ€¦ but its price has jumped to $8 per month. This is a prohibitive price point for academics, many of whom are underemployedâ€¦

Without a Twitter Blue subscription, a current Twitter account holder could only read 600 posts per day; a new Twitter account holder could only read 300. That number has recently been lifted to 1,000 posts for current account holders, but a limit of any kind creates a geography of exclusion to lurking. Attempting to read more than the daily allotted posts, will result in a locked account. Although Musk asserts that the restrictions are temporary, no end date has yet to be announced.

Further, TweetDeck, a tool that made it easy to manage and read the tweets of multiple accounts, is no longer a free service and can only be accessed through what is now called X-premium. Twitterâ€™s API library is also no longer open accessâ€¦ The current monthly cost of being a professional lurker: $1,000â€“$42,000.

Twitter and Facebook also became the first port of call for finding out what was happening right now on a particular topic. Whether that was globally on a breaking news story or hyper-locally to see why those fireworks were going off at 9.50pm on a Tuesday night in September. Today, whether by design or lack of resource, search on both platforms is borked to such a degree that itâ€™s useless. Hashtags, for following topics, conferences and such still work, but the participants and the audience is fracturing.

In terms of getting the message out there, there is something to be said for large platforms that dominate their market. For example, twenty years ago, if you lived in Greater Manchester and wanted a new job, you would buy Thursdayâ€™s Manchester Evening News. It was the outlet for advertising and finding job vacancies. The search engines and web aggregators of today are plenty but arenâ€™t as useful, taking up more time and energy to sifter. Similarly, Twitter was the every personâ€™s PR outlet.

So, where to turn? Facebook is too personal. Instagram and TikTok donâ€™t work in the same way; few can record and cut a hot take in one minute, never mind wanting to watch one. Some have turned to Linkedin, but the live element doesnâ€™t really work there either. There is also an inauthenticity to using LinkedIn where we are projections of our professional image rather than our rounded selves. Whatsapp groups and conversations may be an outlet for the live discussion, say at a conference for example, but itâ€™s hardly open to the web.

Metaâ€™s Threads appears to have legs. Although itâ€™s intrinsically linked to Instagram, people seem to like the way its going for itâ€™s more ephemeral, fun nature. Like the early days of Twitter, perhaps, but unlike the early days of Twitter, it does not have a text search function (yet) and does not have an API allowing for third-party clients (yet) like Tweetbot and Twitterific way back when. There are also the usual Meta issues with data collection, oh and those terms and conditions, which most will let slide if Threads hangs around for the long term. Although beyond grabbing market share from Twitter or even hobbling Muskâ€™s X to the extent that it never bounces back, will Meta keep Threads as an ongoing concern, particularly if they canâ€™t monetise it? Will Threads become so big that it inevitably morphs into the more derided, toxic, pre-Musk Twitter? And if you feel this may happen, is it worth investing time into building a profile on there?

Bluesky and Mastodon are in the peloton for taking the bluebird jersey. Bluesky is dragging its feet a little though maybe playing the long game. Mastodon is arguably best placed to be what Twitter was when it was good. Decentralised and open source, Mastodon offers the promise to be whatever you want it to be. Sadly, the infrastructure for Mastodon around instancesâ€”all of which have their own ownerships, hosting bills and posting rulesâ€”will be confusing to many, and the user experience for finding people and content from those you donâ€™t follow just isnâ€™t there yet, and may never be because of that infrastructure. If you join a niche instance and post on there as you have been doing on Twitter, you may get short shrift from that instanceâ€™s administrator. Perhaps you didnâ€™t refer to the correct source, or what you have posted is self-promotory to the extent that it breaks those rules. Mastodon is not yet built for, and may never be, for the mass.

That said, Mastodon is my current fave. As it utilises the decentralised protocol ActivityPub, it offers a route towards services that cover most of the aspects that made old Twitter good, that aggregate content from wherever it is publishedâ€”whether from websites, blogs, social networksâ€”that are also platform agnostic, thus negating that need for big corporate platforms and, perhaps, why we possibly donâ€™t need another Twitter in the long term. Though itâ€™s arguably closer to a pipe dream. Anyone for RSS?

Bluesky and Mastodon are in the peloton for taking the bluebird jersey. Bluesky is dragging its feet a little though maybe playing the long game. Mastodon is arguably best placed to be what Twitter was when it was good. Decentralised and open source, Mastodon offers the promise to be whatever you want it to be. Sadly, the infrastructure for Mastodon around instancesâ€”all of which have their own ownerships, hosting bills and posting rulesâ€”will be confusing to many, and the user experience for finding people and content from those you donâ€™t follow just isnâ€™t there yet, and may never be because of that infrastructure. If you join a niche instance and post on there as you have been doing on Twitter, you may get short shrift from that instanceâ€™s administrator. Perhaps you didnâ€™t refer to the correct source, or what you have posted is self-promotory to the extent that it breaks those rules. Mastodon is not yet built for, and may never be, for the mass. 

That said, Mastodon is my current fave. As it utilises the decentralised protocol ActivityPub, it offers a route towards services that cover most of the aspects that made old Twitter good, that aggregate content from wherever it is publishedâ€”whether from websites, blogs, social networksâ€”that are also platform agnostic, thus negating that need for big corporate platforms and, perhaps, why we possibly donâ€™t need another Twitter in the long term. Though itâ€™s arguably closer to a pipe dream. Anyone for RSS?

W. David Marx asks: â€˜In the mid-1970s, the Sex Pistols only took two years to move up from squalid London squats to the top of the British pop charts. Why hasn’t a decade been enough time for DIY online video creators to turn their view counts into mainstream stardom?â€™

Marx posits a number of conclusions as to why few if any social media sensations can be called mainstream celebrities. I’m not entirely sold on them, but what he says here rings true and remains a conundrum:

Weâ€™re now at least 15 years into the dominance of online video within youth culture. In the early 2010s, surveys started to find that teenagers were much more interested in YouTube creators than legacy media stars. At the time, it seemed plausible that youth would carry these preferences into their 20s and elevate their favorite creators. That didnâ€™t happen.

The acid test: could the names of social mediaâ€™s most watched replace those in Madonnaâ€™s â€˜Vogueâ€™ and echo through the decades?

items.title: Glastonbury is the size of Manchester City Centre
items.content_html:
The hot weather continues. Perhaps not for much longer as weâ€™re a week away from Glastonbury. Manchester Confidential posted a tweet this week with a map of the city centre overlaid with the boundary of Glastonbury site, which almost blankets it. My money would have been on Glastonbury being much bigger, only on a hunch; I’ve never been.

Another interesting article on Manchester Confidential looked at Manchester Cityâ€”itâ€™s very much their weekâ€”and their previous ground but one: Hyde Road. City (and under their previous moniker of Ardwick AFC) played at the Hyde Road ground from 1887 to 1923. The perimeter was so close to a rail track that as the stadium swelled over time with more enclosures added, the club had no choice but to place one of their stands in a corner behind the track.

Bizarrely then, the railway went through the ground. Not only that, but on occasion, trains got on the way of the action!

items.title: The Terroir
items.content_html:
The hot and dry weather has continued since my daughterâ€™s birthday party last Saturday, bar a downpour of Biblical proportions on Monday that tried to put a damper on Manchester Cityâ€™s treble-winning parade in the city centre. Though as Pep Guardiola remarked, it wouldnâ€™t be a proper Mancunian celebration without rain.

In such sweltering conditions itâ€™s hard not to think, nay fantasise about drinking a cold beer or cider, and cooling your brow with the glass. Steve Dunkley published a brilliant article this week on the concept of terroir in beer. While his label Beer Nouveau maybe on hiatus, Steve continues to write pieces for the website. Terroir is, as Steve puts it, described as the â€˜the soul of the landâ€™ and is generally a term used in winemaking:

Everything grown on that land [is] influenced by the land, and that influence [comes] through in the final glass.

Recently, Steve went to a Manchester Cider Club tasting session where the Little Pomona cidery in Herefordshire showcased seven ciders, all made from Dabinett apples, with each cider made using apples from a different orchard. While each cider had the same ingredients, each cider had subtle differences in flavour. The apples having taken on the characteristics of the land where the trees were grown. The â€˜soul of the orchardsâ€™.

The ingredients for wine and cider are similar being there are few and the provenance of the main ingredient responsible for taste can be guaranteed. Less can be said for beer, apart from say hops. Steve found as much during his in the Manchester Hop Project:

We [were] able to identify a distinct flavour to our regions, all the hops grown in Manchester for instance impart a slight hazelnut flavour to the beer regardless of the hop variety. That is the terroir of Manchester, a bit nutty.

The article also includes a few more French sayings, one of which I was previously unaware: lâ€™esprit dâ€™escalier â€“ a situation of thinking of the perfect reply to someone as weâ€™re leaving and itâ€™s too late to use that witty comeback.â€™ Which immediately made me think of the â€˜jerk storeâ€™ episode of Seinfeld.
